article.description:
Kent Williams scored 24 points and
Jermaine Dearman added 18 to lead Southern Illinois to a 70-62
victory over Creighton (No. 18 ESPN/USA Today, No. 17 AP) on Saturday night.
article.headline: Salukis clinch top seed in conference tourney
article.linkText: S. Illinois beats Creighton, clinches share of MVC title
article.story:
CARBONDALE, Ill. (AP) -- Southern Illinois coach Bruce Weber held
tutoring sessions on how to guard Kyle Korver, and it paid off for
his Salukis.

	   Sophomore Darren Brooks held Korver, who averages 18.4 points,
to just 10 points on 3-for-8 shooting, and Kent Williams scored 24
points and Jermaine Dearman 18 to lead Southern Illinois to a 70-62
victory over Creighton (No. 18 ESPN/USA Today, No. 17 AP) on Saturday night.

	   "Anyone who was going to guard Korver had to come in and watch
film clips,'' Weber said. "We couldn't let him have a run like he
did at their place when he hit three 3s in 38 seconds. You can't
relax on him.''

	   The win clinched the No. 1 seed in the conference tournament and
a share of the league championship for the Salukis (21-5, 15-2
Missouri Valley Conference).

	   Creighton (25-4, 14-3) and Southern Illinois each have one
league game remaining. It was the first win for the Salukis over a
team ranked as high as No. 17 since Nov. 26, 1988, when Southern
Illinois defeated No. 11 Villanova.

	   It was the first win over a ranked conference team for the
Salukis since Jan. 19, 1978, when Southern Illinois topped Indiana
State and Larry Bird.

	   "I thought Darren did a tremendous job on Korver,'' Weber said.
"He's done it all year quietly. He's been tremendous for us all
year. I told Darren at halftime I didn't care if he scored another
bucket -- your job is to keep Korver in single digits. He almost did
it, too.''

	   The win was the Salukis' 27th consecutive home victory, the
fourth-longest active streak in Division I. Southern Illinois
finished 14-0 at home this season.

	   "We laid it all on the table,'' Williams said. "It's been
clicking. We're truly a team in every aspect.''

	   Creighton had won 12 of the last 16, including an 85-76 home
victory on Jan. 18, against Southern Illinois. Michael Lindeman
also scored 10 points for Creighton, while Korver pulled down a
game-high 13 rebounds.

	   "They were just playing aggressive,'' Korver said. "I wasn't
worried about my points. I was worried about getting our team in a
position to win.''

	   A 3-pointer by Dearman gave Southern Illinois a 41-33 lead with
16:26 left. But the Blue Jays went on a 7-0 run to pull within a
point with 12:54 remaining.

	   Southern Illinois then answered with a 13-4 run to take a 54-44
lead with 7:21 to go. The Salukis' biggest lead was 11 at 61-50
with 4:09 showing.

	   Creighton came back with a 10-1 run to trail by two with 1:36
left.

	   "We got it close to 62-60, but they got some offensive rebounds
and that was that,'' Korver said. "We felt like we had momentum,
but that changed pretty fast.''

	   Dearman scored at the 1:05 mark on an assist from Brooks and an
intentional foul by Lindeman on Williams, who sank both free throws
with 37.4 seconds left sealed the win for the Salukis, who added
four more free throws.

	   "I thought the play of the game was when Brooks fed it to
Jermaine and he made a scoop shot in the lane,'' Weber said. "It
wasn't pretty, but things went our way. Jermaine made big plays in
the second half when it counted.''

	   Creighton never had an answer for Williams and Dearman.

	   "We let their big guys (Williams and Dearman) do what they
wanted to do,'' Creighton coach Dana Altman said. "We didn't do a
good job.''

	   Southern Illinois outrebounded Creighton 35-31 and 14-12 on the
offensive boards.

	   "They got a lot of big offensive rebounds,'' Altman said.
"They got 10 in the second half and they scored at least eight
points off them, maybe more. That's too many.''

	   The Blue Jays opened by scoring the game's first seven points.

	   "I told our kids, 'Don't panic,''' Weber said. "It's a long
game. We needed to play 40 minutes of solid basketball. We didn't
need to be perfect.''

	   Back-to-back baskets by Dearman gave Southern Illinois the lead
at 12-11 and began an 11-0 run, giving the Salukis a 19-11 lead.
Creighton was held scoreless for 5:42 before Lindeman scored with
8:18 left in the half.

	   "We didn't have a very good flow at all,'' Altman said. "That
first half, we were pretty stagnant on offense.''

 A jumper and a free throw by Dearman gave the Salukis their
biggest lead of the half at 22-13. Creighton cut the gap to four
points at 25-21, but Creighton outscored Southern Illinois 7-2 in
the final 2:59 of the half to take a 32-23 halftime lead.
